key_issues: Here are the main legal issues extracted from the document:
Depictive similarity between trademarks under Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.
Renewal and abandonment of registered marks under Section 25(3) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.
Visual and phonetic distinctness of trademarks under Section 17 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.
Likelihood of confusion between rival marks under Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.
Requirement to consider trademark as a whole under Section 17 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.
Distinction between goods and services registered in favour of different parties under Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.
Admissibility of evidence in trade mark proceedings under Order XLI Rule 27 of the CPC.
Power to pass order exparte or without notice to other party under Section 151 of the CPC.
metadata.decision_summary:
Here is a comprehensive summary of the case:

**Background:**

The appellant, Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation (TCF), filed an application for registration of a trademark mark in Class 14, consisting of various goods such as jewelry, clocks, keychains, and watches. The office of the Trade Marks Registry issued a First Examination Report (FER) objecting to the registration of the proposed mark under Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, on the ground that it was deceptively similar to two earlier marks: 

 registered in favor of Mr. A. Shrivinasan and 

 registered in favor of Mr. Avathar Varatharajan.

**Legal Issues:**

The main legal issue in this case is whether the proposed mark is deceptively similar to the cited marks, and hence, should be refused registration under Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.

**Arguments:**

The appellant (TCF) contended that:

*   The appellant's mark was phonetically and visually distinct from the cited 

    mark.
*   The overall impression conveyed by the two marks was completely different, and there was no likelihood of confusion.
*   Section 17 of the Trade Marks Act required the rival marks to be seen as a whole, without vivisecting the marks into their individual components.
*   The goods in respect of which the cited markwas registered were also different from the goods in respect of which the appellant sought registration of its mark.

**Court Findings:**

The Senior Examiner rejected the appellant's defense and disallowed registration of the appellant's mark under Section 11(1)1 of the Trade Marks Act on the ground that it was visually and phonetically similar to the cited 

 mark.

**Decision:**

Aggrieved by the decision, TCF appealed to the High Court of Delhi (HCD). The HCD analyzed the similarity between the two marks and held that:

*   While there may be visual similarity between the two marks, there is no evidence to show a likelihood of confusion.
*   Section 17 of the Trade Marks Act requires consideration of the marks as a whole, rather than analyzing individual components.
*   The goods in respect of which both marks are used are different, and registration should not be refused solely on this ground.

**Conclusion:**

Based on these findings, the HCD set aside the appeal and restored the appellant's mark for registration.

Note that the judgment was passed orally and is available digitally signed by SUNIL SINGH NEGI on 28th February 2023.
metadata.full_text:
--- PAGE 1 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001444 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022                                                                                           Page 1 of 8  
 
   
$~2 
* 
IN  THE  HIGH  COURT  OF  DELHI  AT  NEW  DELHI 
+  
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022, I.A. 21666/2022 (Section 151 of 
the CPC) and I.A. 21667/2022 (Order XLI Rule 27 of the CPC) 
 
 
TWENTIETH CENTURY FOX 
FILM CORPORATION  
 
 
 
..... Appellant 
 
 
 
 
Through: 
Mr. Prithvi Singh, Adv. 
 
 
 
 
 
versus 
 
 
THE REGISTRAR 
 
 
 
       
..... Respondent 
Through: 
Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar, 
CGSC with Mr. R. M. Tripathi, Govt. Pleader 
 
CORAM: 
 
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE C.HARI SHANKAR 
 
 
 
 
JUDGMENT (ORAL) 
% 
 
 
 
         27.02.2023 
 
 
1. 
This appeal under Section 91 of the Trade Marks Act assails order 
dated 13th September 2022, passed by the Senior Examiner of Trade 
Marks in the office of the Trade Marks Registry, New Delhi, rejecting 
Application No. 4280126 submitted by the appellant for registration of 
the 
 mark, in Class 14, for ―Alarm clocks; bracelets; busts of 
precious metal; charms; clocks; earrings; jewellery; jewellery cases of 
precious metal; jewellery boxes not of precious metal; jewellery chains; 
decorative key fobs; key chains; key rings; lapel pins; neck chains; 
necklaces; necktie fasteners; nonmonetary coins; ornamental lapel pins; 
pendants; rings; stop watches; tie clips; tie fasteners; tie tacks; wall 
clocks; watch bands; watch cases; watch chains; watch straps; watches; 
wedding bands; wrist watches on proposed to be used basis‖. 
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:28.02.2023
15:39:40
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 2 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001444 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022                                                                                           Page 2 of 8  
 
   
2. 
Consequent to submission of the aforesaid application by the 
appellant, the office of the trademark Registry issued First Examination 
Report (FER) dated 25th September 2019, objecting to the registration of 
the proposed mark under Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, on 
the ground that it was deceptively similar to two earlier marks.  The two 
marks which were cited were (i) 
, registered in favour of Mr. 
A. Shrivinasan and (ii) 
, registered in favour of Mr. Avathar 
Varatharajan. 
 
3. 
Of these two marks, the former mark was not renewed and, 
accordingly, was deemed to be statutorily abandoned under Section 25(3) 
of the Trade Marks Act. 
 
4. 
The appellant, in its reply dated 19th October 2019 to the FER, 
submitted that (i) the appellant’s mark was phonetically and visually 
distinct from the cited 
 mark, (ii) the overall impression 
conveyed by the two marks was completely different and there was, 
therefore, no likelihood of confusion, (iii) Section 17 of the Trade Marks 
Act required the rival marks to be seen as a whole, without vivisecting 
the marks into their individual components, (iv)  the goods in respect of 
which the cited 
 was registered were also different from 
the goods in respect of which the appellant sought registration of its 
mark. 
 
5. 
Mr. Prithvi Singh, learned Counsel for the appellant submits, 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:28.02.2023
15:39:40
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001444 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022                                                                                           Page 3 of 8  
 
   
moreover, that the goods in respect of which the registration of the 
appellant’s mark was sought were essentially towards promotion of the 
movie AVATAR which was released in December 2022. 
 
6. 
The Senior Examiner, by the impugned order dated 13th September 
2022, rejected the aforesaid defence put up by the appellant and 
disallowed registration of the appellant’s mark under Section 11(1)1 of 
the Trade Marks Act on the ground that it was visually and phonetically 
similar to the cited 
mark. 
 
7. 
Aggrieved thereby, the appellant has approached this Court by 
means of the present appeal. 
 
8. 
I have heard Mr. Prithvi Singh, learned Counsel for the appellant 
and Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar, learned Counsel for the 
respondent at some length. 
 
9. 
The only ground on which registration of the 
mark of 
the appellant has been refused, is that it is deceptively similar to the 
 mark registered in favour of Mr. Avathar Varatharajan and 
that the similarity was likely to result in confusion. 
                                          
1 11.  
Relative grounds for refusal of registration. –  
(1)  
Save as provided in Section 12, a trade mark shall not be registered if, because of— 
(a)  
its identity with an earlier trade mark and similarity of goods or services covered by 
the trade mark; or 
(b)  
its similarity to an earlier trade mark and the identity or similarity of the goods or 
services covered by the trade mark, 
there exists a likelihood of confusion on the part of the public, which includes the likelihood of 
association with the earlier trade mark. 
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:28.02.2023
15:39:40
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001444 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022                                                                                           Page 4 of 8  
 
   
 
10. 
It is clear, from a bare reading of Section 11(1) that mere identity 
or similarity of the mark of which registration is sought, and the earlier 
mark, is not sufficient as a ground to reject the application seeking 
registration. Section 11(1) has two clauses. Clause (a) envisages a 
situation in which applicant’s mark is identical to the earlier trademark 
and registration is sought in respect of similar goods and services.  
Clause (b) envisages a situation in which the applicant’s mark is similar 
to an earlier trade mark and the goods and services covered by the two 
marks are identical or similar.  In either case, a third condition is required 
to be satisfied, which is that, owing to the identity or similarity between 
the applicant’s mark and the cited mark, and the identity of similarity 
between the goods covered under two marks, there exists a likelihood of 
confusion on the part of the public, which would include a likelihood of 
association with the earlier trade mark.  
 
11. 
In examining sustainability of the objections raised in the FER, the 
Senior Examiner was required, therefore, to assess whether (i) the 
appellant’s mark was identical or similar to the earlier cited mark 
, (ii) whether the goods and services covered by the two 
marks were identical or similar and (iii) whether, because of these 
factors, a likelihood of confusion on the part of the public existed. 
 
12. 
Applying these tests to the case at hand, the position that emerges 
is, as I find, thus: 
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:28.02.2023
15:39:40
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001444 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022                                                                                           Page 5 of 8  
 
   
(i) 
It cannot be said that the applicant’s 
 mark is 
identical or similar to the cited 
 mark.  No doubt, the 
two marks are phonetically similar and, perhaps, even identical. 
However, mere phonetic similarity is insufficient to render the 
marks identical or similar within the meaning of Section 11(1).  
The identity or similarity has to be such as would result in 
likelihood of confusion on the part of the public.   
 
(ii) 
The cited 
 consists of the word ―AVATHAR‖ 
in English and Tamil, with the sketch of the face of a lady 
alongside.  It is the composite mark, as such, which has been 
registered.  When comparing marks for the purpose of assessing 
infringement, Section 172 of the Trade Marks Act specifically 
proscribes vivisection of marks into its individual components, and 
holds that where a mark is registered as a whole, exclusivity is 
conferred on the whole mark, and not on individual parts thereof.  
It is this very claim to exclusivity in the earlier mark, and the 
possibility of confusion, were the two marks to be simultaneously 
registered, that forms the foundation of the proscription against 
registration found in Section 11(1).  The possibility of confusion 
                                          
2 17.  
Effect of registration of parts of a mark. –  
(1)  
When a trade mark consists of several matters, its registration shall confer on the proprietor 
exclusive right to the use of the trade mark taken as a whole. 
(2)  
Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), when a trade mark –  
(a)  
contains any part –  
(i)  
which is not the subject of a separate application by the proprietor for 
registration as a trade mark; or 
(ii)  
which is not separately registered by the proprietor as a trade mark; or 
(b)  
contains any matter which is common to the trade or is otherwise of a non-
distinctive character, 
the registration thereof shall not confer any exclusive right in the matter forming only a part of the 
whole of the trade mark so registered. 
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:28.02.2023
15:39:40
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001444 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022                                                                                           Page 6 of 8  
 
   
has, in either case, to be viewed from the perspective of the same 
mythical gentleman of average intelligence and imperfect 
recollection, first invoked by the Supreme Court in Corn Products 
Refining Co. v. Shangrila Food Products Ltd3.  The impression, 
created on the ―mind’s eye‖ of such a gentleman is of the entire 
earlier mark, seen as a whole.  The principle that composite marks 
are to be compared as a whole, unless individual parts thereof are 
registered separately, is a thread that runs through the Trade Marks 
Act.  One cannot, therefore, extract, from the cited 
 
mark, only the word ―AVATHAR‖ in order to compare it with the 
appellant’s 
mark.  The marks are to be compared as a 
whole. 
 
(iii) Viewed thus, it is clear that there is no similarity between 
the 
cited 
 
mark 
and 
the 
appellant’s 
mark, except the phonetic similarity between the 
words ―AVATHAR‖ and ―AVATAR‖.  The cited 
 
mark contains the sketch of a lady as well as the word 
―AVATHAR‖ written both in English and Tamil.  These features 
are completely absent in the appellant’s 
 mark.  No 
person of average intelligence and imperfect recollection would, 
therefore, confuse the cited 
mark with the appellant’s 
 mark.  It is extremely unlikely that the average 
                                          
3 AIR 1960 SC 142 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:28.02.2023
15:39:40
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001444 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022                                                                                           Page 7 of 8  
 
   
consumer would regard 
 as merely an avatar4 of 
.  
 
(iv) 
The Court is of the opinion that the Senior Examiner erred 
in 
merely 
emphasising 
the 
phonetic 
similarity 
between 
―AVATHAR‖ and ―AVATAR‖, without recognising the fact that 
the cited 
 mark was a composite device mark 
containing a sketch, as well as the word AVATHAR written in two 
languages, compositely registered, with no registration of its 
individual parts or elements.  The marks, to reiterate, were required 
to be compared as a whole and, when so compared, they cannot be 
treated as similar, much less identical. 
 
13. 
In that view of the matter, it is not necessary for this Court to enter 
into the exercise of comparing the goods or classes in respect of which 
registration was sought, as identity or similarity of the marks and identity 
or similarity of the goods are required to be cumulatively satisfied for 
either of clauses (a) and (b) of Section 11(1) to apply, the conjunctive 
link, in each clause, being ―and‖, not ―or‖. If the competing marks are 
neither identical nor similar, therefore, no occasion arises to compare the 
goods or services in respect of which the marks are registered, or 
proposed to be registered.   
 
14. 
Moreover, and at the cost of repetition, in view of the difference 
between the two marks, there was no likelihood of confusion, on the part 
                                          
4 ―Incarnation‖, in vernacular 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:28.02.2023
15:39:40
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001444 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022                                                                                           Page 8 of 8  
 
   
of the public, between them.  The third requirement of Section 11(1) is 
also, therefore, not satisfied. 
 
15. 
I am, therefore, of the considered opinion that the Senior Examiner 
has erred in rejecting the appellant’s application. 
 
16. 
The impugned order dated 13th September 2022 is, therefore, 
quashed and set aside. 
 
17. 
As appellant’s mark was never advertised, having been rejected at 
an initial stage, the Registrar is directed to advertise the mark and 
proceed thereafter in accordance with law. 
 
18. 
The appeal stands allowed in the aforesaid terms.  
 
19. 
Miscellaneous applications do not survive for consideration and 
stand disposed of. 
 
20. 
Let this order be uploaded on the website of this Court within 24 
hours. 
 
 
C. HARI SHANKAR, J 
FEBRUARY 27, 2023 
rb 
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:28.02.2023
15:39:40
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Case Header and Parties
tree_structure.summary:
Here is a summary of the document:

**Case Details**

* **Case Name:** Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation v. The Registrar
* **Case Number:** C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022, I.A. 21666/2022 and I.A. 21667/2022
* **Neutral Citation Number:** 2023/DHC/001444
* **Court:** High Court of Delhi at New Delhi

**Parties**

* **Appellant:** Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation (represented by Mr. Prithvi Singh)
* **Respondent:** The Registrar (represented by Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar and Mr. R.M. Tripathi)

**Background**

The appellant, Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation, applied to register a trade mark for various goods such as jewelry, watches, and accessories in Class 14.

**First Examination Report (FER)**

* The FER was issued by the Trade Marks Registry on September 25, 2019, objecting to registration of the proposed mark under Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act 1999.
* The objection was based on alleged deceptively similar marks registered in favor of Mr. A. Shrivinasan and Mr. Avathar Varatharajan.

**Proceedings**

* The appellant submitted a reply to the FER on October 19, 2019, arguing that their mark was phonetically and visually distinct from the cited marks and that there was no likelihood of confusion.
* The appeal under Section 91 of the Trade Marks Act assailed an order dated September 13, 2022, passed by the Senior Examiner of Trade Marks rejecting the application.

**Judgment**

A judgment (oral) was pronounced on February 27, 2023, but details are not available.

nodes.title: Page 1
nodes.summary:
**PDF Source:** 43. Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation v. The Registrar.pdf

**Summary:**

C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) No.162/2022 was filed by Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation (Appellant) against The Registrar (Respondent). The Appellant sought to register a trademark for various goods, including jewelry and clocks, under Class 14.

**Key Points:**

* Section 91 of the Trade Marks Act governs this appeal.
* Order dated September 13, 2022, was passed by Senior Examiner of Trade Marks in the office of the Trade Marks Registry, New Delhi, rejecting Application No. 4280126 for trademark registration.
* The Appellant is appealing against the rejection order to register its proposed mark for use on various goods in Class 14.

**Proceedings:**

* C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) No.162/2022 was filed by Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation (Appellant).
* I.A.21666/2022 and I.A.21667/2022 were also mentioned, involving amendments to CPC (Code of Civil Procedure).

**Notable Dates:**

* Order dated September 13, 2022: Rejection order passed by Senior Examiner of Trade Marks.
* February 27, 2023: Judgement was delivered orally by HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE C.HARI SHANKAR.

**Parties:**

* Twentieth Century

nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 2 from the PDF:

**Document:** Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation v. The Registrar.pdf (Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001444)

**Summary:**

After the appellant, Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation, submitted an application for trademark registration, the office of the trademark Registry issued a First Examination Report (FER) dated September 25, 2019, objecting to the registration due to deceptively similar marks.

The cited marks were:

1. (registered in favor of Mr. A. Shrivinasan)
2. (registered in favor of Mr. Avathar Varatharajan)

However, the former mark was not renewed and was deemed statutorily abandoned under Section 25(3) of the Trade Marks Act.

The appellant submitted a reply dated October 19, 2019, arguing that its mark is phonetically and visually distinct from the cited marks, with no likelihood of confusion. The appellant also argued that Section 17 of the Trade Marks Act requires considering rival marks as a whole, without dissecting them into individual components.

**Key Dates:** September 25, 2019 (FER), October 19, 2019 (appellant's reply)

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
**Court Case Summary**

**Case Details:**

* Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001444
* C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022 (High Court of Delhi at New Delhi)
* Parties:
	+ Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation (Appellant)
	+ Mr. Avathar Varatharajan and others (Respondents)

**Background:**

The appeal was filed by Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation against the rejection of their trademark application for "Avatar" by the Senior Examiner under Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act.

**Key Facts:**

* The goods in question were promotional materials for the movie AVATAR, released in December 2022.
* The Senior Examiner rejected the application on grounds that the mark was deceptively similar to an existing trademark.

**Arguments and Decisions:**

* The Appellant argued that the registration of their mark should not be refused as it is not required to prove identity or similarity between the marks alone, but rather a likelihood of confusion among the public.
* The High Court held that the Senior Examiner must assess three conditions:
	1. Whether the marks are identical or similar
	2. Whether the goods and services covered by the two marks are identical or similar
	3. Whether there is a likelihood of confusion on the part of the public
* The Court found that only one condition was examined by the Senior Examiner, regarding the similarity between the marks.

**Source:**

43. Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation v. The Registrar (2023/DHC/001444)

nodes.title: Page 3
nodes.summary:
**Summary of page 3 of PDF "43. Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation v. The Registrar"](https://example.com/pdf/43.Twentieth.Century.Fox.Film.Corporation.v.The.Registrar.pdf)

The case is **C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022**, with a Neutral Citation Number of **2023/DHC/001444**. The appellant, Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation, sought registration for a trade mark related to the movie "Avatar", released in December 2022. However, the Senior Examiner rejected their application under Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act on grounds of deceptively similarity with an existing trademark.

The arguments presented by the appellant centered around the fact that their goods were essentially promotional material for the movie and thus distinct from the cited mark. The issue at hand is whether registration of the mark would result in confusion among the public.

**Key dates and parties involved:**

* December 2022: Release of the movie "Avatar"
* September 13, 2022: Senior Examiner's impugned order rejecting the appellant's application
* February 28, 2023: Hearing by the court
* Mr. Prithvi Singh (appellant's counsel)
* Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar (respondent's counsel)
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001444 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022                                                                                           Page 3 of 8  
 
   
moreover, that the goods in respect of which the registration of the 
appellant’s mark was sought were essentially towards promotion of the 
movie AVATAR which was released in December 2022. 
 
6. 
The Senior Examiner, by the impugned order dated 13th September 
2022, rejected the aforesaid defence put up by the appellant and 
disallowed registration of the appellant’s mark under Section 11(1)1 of 
the Trade Marks Act on the ground that it was visually and phonetically 
similar to the cited 
mark. 
 
7. 
Aggrieved thereby, the appellant has approached this Court by 
means of the present appeal. 
 
8. 
I have heard Mr. Prithvi Singh, learned Counsel for the appellant 
and Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar, learned Counsel for the 
respondent at some length. 
 
9. 
The only ground on which registration of the 
mark of 
the appellant has been refused, is that it is deceptively similar to the 
 mark registered in favour of Mr. Avathar Varatharajan and 
that the similarity was likely to result in confusion. 
                                          
1 11.  
Relative grounds for refusal of registration. –  
(1)  
Save as provided in Section 12, a trade mark shall not be registered if, because of— 
(a)  
its identity with an earlier trade mark and similarity of goods or services covered by 
the trade mark; or 
(b)  
its similarity to an earlier trade mark and the identity or similarity of the goods or 
services covered by the trade mark, 
there exists a likelihood of confusion on the part of the public, which includes the likelihood of 
association with the earlier trade mark.

nodes.title: Page 4
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 4 from the PDF "43. Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation v. The Registrar.pdf":

The court is examining an application for trademark registration by Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation (Appellant). In assessing the objection raised in the Registrar's Examination Report (FER), the Senior Examiner must determine:

1. Whether the Appellant's mark is identical or similar to the earlier cited mark.
2. Whether the goods and services covered by the two marks are identical or similar.
3. Whether, due to these factors, a likelihood of confusion on the part of the public exists.

The court applies these tests and concludes that:

* The Appellant's mark is not necessarily "similar" to the earlier citied mark (Section 11(1) clause b).
* To reject the application, a requirement of "identity or similarity between the goods covered under two marks" must be met.
* A likelihood of confusion on the part of the public is required.

Source: pdf file "43. Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation v. The Registrar.pdf" ( Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001444).
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001444 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022                                                                                           Page 4 of 8  
 
   
 
10. 
It is clear, from a bare reading of Section 11(1) that mere identity 
or similarity of the mark of which registration is sought, and the earlier 
mark, is not sufficient as a ground to reject the application seeking 
registration. Section 11(1) has two clauses. Clause (a) envisages a 
situation in which applicant’s mark is identical to the earlier trademark 
and registration is sought in respect of similar goods and services.  
Clause (b) envisages a situation in which the applicant’s mark is similar 
to an earlier trade mark and the goods and services covered by the two 
marks are identical or similar.  In either case, a third condition is required 
to be satisfied, which is that, owing to the identity or similarity between 
the applicant’s mark and the cited mark, and the identity of similarity 
between the goods covered under two marks, there exists a likelihood of 
confusion on the part of the public, which would include a likelihood of 
association with the earlier trade mark.  
 
11. 
In examining sustainability of the objections raised in the FER, the 
Senior Examiner was required, therefore, to assess whether (i) the 
appellant’s mark was identical or similar to the earlier cited mark 
, (ii) whether the goods and services covered by the two 
marks were identical or similar and (iii) whether, because of these 
factors, a likelihood of confusion on the part of the public existed. 
 
12. 
Applying these tests to the case at hand, the position that emerges 
is, as I find, thus: 
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:28.02.2023
15:39:40
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
The document is a High Court of Delhi at New Delhi judgment in the case Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation v. The Registrar, dated March 8, 2023 (Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001444).

**Legal Proceeding:** C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022

**Parties:** 

* Appellant: Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation
* Respondent: The Registrar (not specified)

**Arguments:**

The respondent applied to register the trademark "AVATAR" under Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act, but the application was opposed by the appellant. The court examined whether there is similarity between the marks.

**Court's Decision:** 

* The court held that mere phonetic similarity between two marks is insufficient for a finding of similarity within the meaning of Section 11(1).
* It cannot be inferred from Section 172 of the Trade Marks Act that registration of individual components (such as words) grants exclusivity if registered together.
* The court applied the principle of comparing composite marks as a whole, rather than dissecting them into their individual components.

**Key Findings:**

* No similarity between the cited mark and the appellant's AVATAR except for phonetic similarity between the words AVATHAR and AVATAR.
* The cited mark includes a sketch of a lady and the word AVATHAR in English and Tamil, while the appellant's mark does not contain these features.

**References:**

Corn Products Refining Co. v. Shangrila Food Products Ltd (Supreme Court judgment)

The PDF source is "43. Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation v. The Registrar.pdf"
tree_structure.pdf_source: 43. Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation v. The Registrar.pdf

nodes.title: Page 5
nodes.summary:
Here's a summary of page 5 from the PDF:

**Case:** Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation v. The Registrar

**Court:** High Court of Delhi at New Delhi

**Case Number:** C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022

**Page Number:** 5 of 8 (from PDF: 43. Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation v. The Registrar.pdf)

The court discusses the issue of infringement under Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act. It is argued that:

* The applicant's mark cannot be said to be identical or similar to the cited mark, solely based on phonetic similarity.
* Mere phonetic similarity does not establish identity or similarity between marks.
* The cited mark consists of a composite whole (English and Tamil words with a sketch) which has been registered as such. Section 172 prohibits dissecting marks into individual components for comparison.

The court is referring to Section 17(1) of the Trade Marks Act, which states that registration confers exclusive right to use the trade mark "taken as a whole". 

**Note**: The PDF source: Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation v. The Registrar.pdf
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001444 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022                                                                                           Page 5 of 8  
 
   
(i) 
It cannot be said that the applicant’s 
 mark is 
identical or similar to the cited 
 mark.  No doubt, the 
two marks are phonetically similar and, perhaps, even identical. 
However, mere phonetic similarity is insufficient to render the 
marks identical or similar within the meaning of Section 11(1).  
The identity or similarity has to be such as would result in 
likelihood of confusion on the part of the public.   
 
(ii) 
The cited 
 consists of the word ―AVATHAR‖ 
in English and Tamil, with the sketch of the face of a lady 
alongside.  It is the composite mark, as such, which has been 
registered.  When comparing marks for the purpose of assessing 
infringement, Section 172 of the Trade Marks Act specifically 
proscribes vivisection of marks into its individual components, and 
holds that where a mark is registered as a whole, exclusivity is 
conferred on the whole mark, and not on individual parts thereof.  
It is this very claim to exclusivity in the earlier mark, and the 
possibility of confusion, were the two marks to be simultaneously 
registered, that forms the foundation of the proscription against 
registration found in Section 11(1).  The possibility of confusion 
                                          
2 17.  
Effect of registration of parts of a mark. –  
(1)  
When a trade mark consists of several matters, its registration shall confer on the proprietor 
exclusive right to the use of the trade mark taken as a whole. 
(2)  
Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), when a trade mark –  
(a)  
contains any part –  
(i)  
which is not the subject of a separate application by the proprietor for 
registration as a trade mark; or 
(ii)  
which is not separately registered by the proprietor as a trade mark; or 
(b)  
contains any matter which is common to the trade or is otherwise of a non-
distinctive character, 
the registration thereof shall not confer any exclusive right in the matter forming only a part of the 
whole of the trade mark so registered. 
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:28.02.2023
15:39:40
Signature Not Verified

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary:
This summary focuses on legal facts from page 6 of the PDF file "43. Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation v. The Registrar.pdf" ( Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001444 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022).

The Delhi High Court considers the comparison between the appellant's mark (AVATAR) and a cited trademark that contains "AVATHAR", with additional features.

Key legal facts:

* Composite marks are compared as a whole unless individual parts are registered separately.
* Citing Corn Products Refining Co. v. Shangrila Food Products Ltd (AIR 1960 SC 142), the court emphasizes the importance of considering the impression created on the "mind's eye" of an average person.
* The marks are distinct, with no similarity except for phonetic similarity between "AVATHAR" and "AVATAR".
* The cited trademark contains additional features (a lady sketch and text in English and Tamil) not present in the appellant's mark.

The court concludes that it is unlikely for an average person to confuse the cited mark with the appellant's mark.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001444 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022                                                                                           Page 6 of 8  
 
   
has, in either case, to be viewed from the perspective of the same 
mythical gentleman of average intelligence and imperfect 
recollection, first invoked by the Supreme Court in Corn Products 
Refining Co. v. Shangrila Food Products Ltd3.  The impression, 
created on the ―mind’s eye‖ of such a gentleman is of the entire 
earlier mark, seen as a whole.  The principle that composite marks 
are to be compared as a whole, unless individual parts thereof are 
registered separately, is a thread that runs through the Trade Marks 
Act.  One cannot, therefore, extract, from the cited 
 
mark, only the word ―AVATHAR‖ in order to compare it with the 
appellant’s 
mark.  The marks are to be compared as a 
whole. 
 
(iii) Viewed thus, it is clear that there is no similarity between 
the 
cited 
 
mark 
and 
the 
appellant’s 
mark, except the phonetic similarity between the 
words ―AVATHAR‖ and ―AVATAR‖.  The cited 
 
mark contains the sketch of a lady as well as the word 
―AVATHAR‖ written both in English and Tamil.  These features 
are completely absent in the appellant’s 
 mark.  No 
person of average intelligence and imperfect recollection would, 
therefore, confuse the cited 
mark with the appellant’s 
 mark.  It is extremely unlikely that the average 
                                          
3 AIR 1960 SC 142

By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
Here is a summary of the court decision from the provided PDF:

**Case Details**

* Case No.: C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022
* Court: High Court of Delhi at New Delhi
* Date: February 27, 2023
* Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001444

**Parties**

* Appellant: Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation (Fox)
* Respondent: Not Provided (TH...)

**Background**

* Fox applied to register the trademark "AVATHAR" for class 9 and 41 goods/services.
* The Registrar rejected the application, citing similarity with the registered mark "AVATAR".

**Arguments**

* Fox argued that the marks are not similar, as "AVATHAR" is a composite device mark with a sketch and two languages, whereas "AVATAR" is a single word.
* Fox contended that the Senior Examiner erred in comparing only the phonetic similarity between the marks.

**Decision**

* The Court held that the Senior Examiner erred in rejecting the application.
* The Court quashed and set aside the impugned order dated September 13, 2022.
* The Court directed the Registrar to advertise Fox's mark and proceed with the registration process.
* Fox's appeal was allowed.

**Ruling**

* The Court found that the marks "AVATHAR" and "AVATAR" are not similar, and therefore, there is no likelihood of confusion among consumers.
* There is no mention of any amounts or financial disputes in the decision.
tree_structure.pdf_source: 43. Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation v. The Registrar.pdf

nodes.title: Page 7
nodes.summary:
**Summary of Page 7**

In the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi case **C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022**, Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation v. The Registrar (2023/DHC/001444), on page 7, the court deliberates on the similarity between two trademarks:

* "AVATAR"
* "AVATHAR"

**Key Points**

* The Senior Examiner erred in emphasizing phonetic similarity without considering the marks as a whole.
* The marks are composite device marks with a sketch and word(s) written in multiple languages, making them distinct.
* Identity or similarity of the marks is required for Section 11(1) to apply; since the marks are not similar, there's no need to compare goods or services.
* No likelihood of confusion exists between the two trademarks.

**PDF Source**: 43. Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation v. The Registrar.pdf
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001444 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022                                                                                           Page 7 of 8  
 
   
consumer would regard 
 as merely an avatar4 of 
.  
 
(iv) 
The Court is of the opinion that the Senior Examiner erred 
in 
merely 
emphasising 
the 
phonetic 
similarity 
between 
―AVATHAR‖ and ―AVATAR‖, without recognising the fact that 
the cited 
 mark was a composite device mark 
containing a sketch, as well as the word AVATHAR written in two 
languages, compositely registered, with no registration of its 
individual parts or elements.  The marks, to reiterate, were required 
to be compared as a whole and, when so compared, they cannot be 
treated as similar, much less identical. 
 
13. 
In that view of the matter, it is not necessary for this Court to enter 
into the exercise of comparing the goods or classes in respect of which 
registration was sought, as identity or similarity of the marks and identity 
or similarity of the goods are required to be cumulatively satisfied for 
either of clauses (a) and (b) of Section 11(1) to apply, the conjunctive 
link, in each clause, being ―and‖, not ―or‖. If the competing marks are 
neither identical nor similar, therefore, no occasion arises to compare the 
goods or services in respect of which the marks are registered, or 
proposed to be registered.   
 
14. 
Moreover, and at the cost of repetition, in view of the difference 
between the two marks, there was no likelihood of confusion, on the part

nodes.title: Page 8
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 8 of the PDF file (Source: Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation v. The Registrar.pdf):

**Case Details**

* Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001444
* C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022
* Appeal Hearing Date: February 27, 2023

**Judgment and Decision**

The court allowed the appeal, quashing and setting aside the impugned order dated September 13, 2022. The Senior Examiner had erred in rejecting the appellant's application.

* The decision held that the requirements of Section 11(1) were not satisfied, specifically clause (i) which requires a genuine intention to use an unregistered trademark.
* The court directed the Registrar to advertise the mark and proceed further as per law.
* The appeal was allowed in terms mentioned above.
* Miscellaneous applications did not survive for consideration and were disposed of.

**Key Players**

* C. HARI SHANKAR, J - Presiding Judge
* SUNIL SINGH NEGI - Digitally Signed the order

Note: The focus of this summary is on legal facts, proceedings, arguments, decisions, dates, names, and amounts. It remains under 200 words and mentions the PDF source.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001444 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 162/2022                                                                                           Page 8 of 8  
 
   
of the public, between them.  The third requirement of Section 11(1) is 
also, therefore, not satisfied. 
 
15. 
I am, therefore, of the considered opinion that the Senior Examiner 
has erred in rejecting the appellant’s application. 
 
16. 
The impugned order dated 13th September 2022 is, therefore, 
quashed and set aside. 
 
17. 
As appellant’s mark was never advertised, having been rejected at 
an initial stage, the Registrar is directed to advertise the mark and 
proceed thereafter in accordance with law. 
 
18. 
The appeal stands allowed in the aforesaid terms.  
 
19. 
Miscellaneous applications do not survive for consideration and 
stand disposed of. 
 
20. 
Let this order be uploaded on the website of this Court within 24 
hours. 
 
 
C. HARI SHANKAR, J 
FEBRUARY 27, 2023
